text: Aroma is malty and light spicey with darker fruits. Taste is somewhat malty, light burnt sugars and chocolate. Light yeast spicey and sweet finish.

Flaska från SB, provning med ölsällskapet. Ca 2 år gammal. Mörkbrun/kastanjebrun med krämbeiget skum. Söt doft med mängder av torkad frukt, muscovadosocker, lite kastanj, kola och längre bak en gnutta apelsinskal. Mediumkropp. Stor sötma även i smaken med muscovadosocker, torkad frukt, bränt socker. Lite värmande alkohol och beska och en väldigt lätt rökig ton.
Rating this off the cuff. Mobile app neglected to record online so I lost my original rating.
Sweet. But I guess thats how it should be with an Abbey Dubbel. Brown sugar, syrup, with some spices as well. A really good beer!

Pours dark brow/cola with a head that quickly disappears. Smells of brown sugar. Tastes sweet, slight raisin or prune hidden beneath,. Yeast, but not as strong as some Abbey-style ales. Alcohol is hidden by the sweetness, A bit of a burnt malt/coffee finish.

This is rated high, but I prefer a Westmalle, Rochefort or a Chimay to this.

Murky brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, caramel/molasses, & dark fruit; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel/syrup, dark fruit, and some spice; Nicely balanced. On the sweet side but solid.

Appearance: clear deep amber with a short, short-lived light tan head and no lacing. (3/5) Aroma: brown sugar, dark fruit, cola, mild coffee and chocolate. (7/10) Taste: moderate sweet, very mild bitter. (7/10) Palate: medium to full body, soft carbonation, mildly warming finish. (4/5)

A decent enough dubbel, but it feels a bit light for the style to me, even though the carbonation tends to the soft. Theres a little hop bitterness coming through, and even just the faintest hint of sourness, that isnt indicated by standard guidelines. Not so much an abbey dubbel, perhaps, as an American dubbel? (14/20)

Draught at the Anderson Valley Taproom, Boonville, CA. Rated on May 8th.
Clear reddish brown colour with a tiny tan head. 
Sweet dried fruits, brown sugar, mild yeast, sweet malt and mild hoppy notes in the aroma. 
The flavour is brown sugar, sweetness, dark fruits, yeast, hoppy bitterness, alcohol and dark malt. Strong.

[Tap] Clear and light brown in color with a pillowy head on top. Sweet breads, dark fruit and molasses in the nose. Flavors of brown sugar, bread, caramel, candied plums, sticky malts and mild alcohol. Not much bitterness at all. Very sweet and a little syrupy. Tasting notes from 9/2014.
Poured from a bottle it is a clear dark amber with no head. The aroma is coffee the taste is sweet raisins
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home. Pours a light clear cola brown with a tan head. Aroma of toffee. Flavors of raisins and toast. Medium bodied and medium carbonation. Smooth slightly sweet finish.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy reddish brown color with white head. Brown sugar, plum, malty, fig aromas. Dark fruit, malty, candi sugar, fig flavors. Pretty nice drinking American version of a dubbel.

Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma of candied sugar and malt. The taste is sweet with a slightly bitter dark cherry offset finishing with an spicy and slightly sharp hop bitterness finishing the beer crisply. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from bottle. Candied fruit aroma. Pours a dark brown with tan head. Has a medium sweet taste. Medium bodied with a sticky texture. Very nice dubbel.
22 oz bottle. Aroma: malty, boozy, and skunky with hints of brown sugar, plum, raisin, biscuit, and Sweet Tarts candy. Taste/Palate: sweet, thick, and crisp; finishes tart.

From bottle to tulip. Thick bread malt with moderateate dark fruit (raisin) and slight chocolate. Pours a ruby-brown with strong ruby highlighting throughout. Light brown head leaves quickly after covering the top. Looks slightly oily like a cognac. Taste is bread loaf with slight oxidized like flavor. Molasses and caramel in reserve. Moderate high roastiness is noticeable on the end, with slight alcohol warmth.

from tap at beertemple had clean, lasting head. dried fruit, plum, black cherry, sweet, Belgian, so much more. long lasting taste. take your time. let the alcohol work. even grainy whiskey aromas back there. I need some 36 month gouda now... best out of anderson valley so far.

Bottle, aged 3 years. Served in a tulip. Pours murky dark brown with no head. Served too cold, but I was thirsty and didnt want to wait for it to warm. Still had solid aromatics straight out of the fridge. Classic dark fruited Belgian nose. Raisins, plums, candi sugar, etc. Medium-plus sweet flavor. Medium body, soft carbonations, sticky texture, and a yeasty, prune-skin bitter finish. Quite nice.

Looks like a dark leather belt with a thin off white head. Nice raisin, tobacco, leather, burnt toffee, spices, booze, wood scents. So much good stuff going on here. On the tongue, dark fruitcake, bubblegum, burnt bread and all the smells come out to play. Mid-full bodied, oily and with mid carbonation, this is a real damn treat. Definitely warms the soul up very quickly. I really enjoyed this brew, havent had a tonne of Dubbels but this is a fine one!

"great body, heavy alcohol and spice on the nose. smoother than i was expecting. this is one of the best beers they make. Boonviile...Belgian. they dont seem to go together, but this one really works. way good on tap! bottle 3.9....tap 4.1"

Refrigerated bottle poured into a Trappist glass. Dark brown with medium brown highlights and small beige head.  Aroma is dark candy sugar, medium body, low carbonation, and some small-bubble lacing. Taste is earthy, dark fruit (mostly raisins), some spice, some sugar, and dry finish.
Great belgain abbey ale. Nice dried fruit flavor slight spicey flavor. Great combination. Loved this beer, kinda reminds me of Brothers thelonious.

Ill start by saying "Wow!" I love this beer. The color is a nice dark brown. The aroma has the usual Belgian malty, sweet, fruity, and spicy notes to it. The flavor matches up to that. Belgian spice is a dominant flavor, with a rich caramel sweet malt backdrop. The 9% alcohol content lends a touch of warmth but isnt burning. To my taste its a nearly perfect beer.
Bomber. From old notes. Strong, sweet malts, chocolate and caramel, spicy Belgian yeast. Reminiscent of Westmalle Dubbel. Very well done.
Sensory overload in all aspects. Too he honest its a bit much. Salted Carmel, honey, a hint of lime. So very complex.

Bottle from systembolaget. Smells sweet with a touch of raisins, caramel, malt and dark chocolate. Pours a dark amber red color with a small white head. Taste is very round. Hints of sweets and fruits such as caramel and apple. It has a creamy almost ale-like finish which has a subtle and nice feeling in the mouth.

Aroma is light malts and slight yeast and sugar candy also some molasses notes here. . Taste is a smooth bitterness up front that finishes smooth and accompanied by slight liquor warmth. Tastes of caramel, apple, plum and sweet Belgian sugar here. Appearance is a clear yet quite dark amber. The thin head disappears faster than desired.
Keg at the Hanging Bat. A nice dubbel, rich caramel, fruity, toffee, berries.
Bloody lovely. Has a bottle at room temp and one cold. As a Brit preferred room temp. Need another
Keg at The Hanging Bat. Pours clear dark chestnut brown, thin off-white head. Aromas of spice, dark sugar, Belgian yeast. All good stuff. Taste does not disappoint. Enjoyed this.
Thank you Jeff for the bottle. Aroma is chocolate, clove and earthiness. Smooth malt body, clove chocolate and noble hops in taste. Tasty brew.

22 ounce bottle into chalice, no bottle dating. Pours fairly crystal clear deep ruby brown color with a 1 finger fairly dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with some moderate streaming carbonation. Aromas of raisin, plum, fig, pear, apple, light banana, caramel, toast, candi sugar, brown bread, light chocolate, clove, light pepper, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast and balanced dark/bready malt sweetness; with solid strength. Taste of raisin, plum, fig, pear, apple, light banana, caramel, toast, biscuit, candi sugar, brown bread, light chocolate, clove, pepper, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Moderate amount of earthy yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, plum, fig, pear, apple, light banana, caramel, toast, biscuit, light chocolate, candi sugar, clove, pepper, herbal, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice complexity and robustness of dark/bready malt and fruity/spicy yeast ester flavors; with a nice malt/yeast flavor balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth and moderately slick/crisp mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice dubbel. Good balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast and dark/bready malt flavors; and smooth to sip on for the ABV. A nicely enjoyable offering.

Delicious aromas of spices, sugar and dried fruit. Dark brown and reddish color. Deep intense flavors of caramelized figs and raisins. Toffee, caramel, fermented berries. Lots of things going on with this beer, I really really enjoy everything about it!

Caramel, raisin, cherry, and burnt sugar aromas. Dark brown with red highlights, and a lasting, minimal khaki head. Initial flavors of vanilla and caramel, dark fruit, walnut, and savory, funky earth. Medium bodied, complex but very refreshing, finishes with lingering yeasty notes.

How: Bottle.
Where: At Halles, courtesy of Klas.
Appearance: Dark brown colour with a beige head.
Aroma: Malt, caramel, dried fruit, plum, hops.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Roasted malt, dried fruit, caramel, hops.

Great coloring with depth and impenetrable to light. Dark-amber that would trap an insect for a million years to be unearthed by Jurassic park scientists. 

Foam, beach foam at the shore-line, just enough to make your day at the beach memorable. Enough to trap sea-life.

Dubbel forward but fails to stay the night. Get in, get off, get out. True Belgians will stay through the night and make breakfast. The initial onslaught leads me to believe I am enjoying a certified Belgian, but alas a copy. 

I did note the 9% on the label...that's why I purchased this unknown to me. Yes I like the warmth, but I also enjoy a tasty brew. You my friend failed in the end to follow-through. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

ar: caramel, bread, hay, floral, earthy, yeasty, alcohol, butterscotch, spices, dark dried fruits. 
ap: hazy ruby/brown color, small beige head.
t: heavy sweetness, lightly bitter, slightly salty and roasty, abv evident, yeasty, but less so than its Belgian counterparts.
p: fullbodied, lively carbonation, warming and sweet finish.
O: One of the better brews Ive tried from this brewery.

Pours a clear dark brown with a small off white head that almost completely disappears fairly quickly. Aroma is rich sweet maltiness, caramel, dark dried fruits(rasins, plums), faint chocolate, faint alcohol and light spicy phenols. Flavour is rich sweet maltiness, spicy phenols(mostly clove like), faint alcohol, caramel, plums, rasins, mild bitterness(more so of the noble hop variety) and a medium dry finish.
Aroma is caramel/toffee, very light fruit and slightly dirty/earthy. The flavor is caramel, light fruit, slightly dirty/earthy and mildly tart/sour finish.

From the 650 ml. bottle. The pour is chestnut-mahogany brown with a light brown head that lingers momentarily before fading to a ring. The aroma is full of dark malts, brown sugar, fig, plum and other dark fruits, and a vague buttery sensation. That could be the yeast. The body is medium to full. The taste is over-the-top sweet with a strong malt character and a clean finish. A little more sweet than I prefer but quite drinkable.

22oz bottle picked up at the state store 
Pours clear dark ruby/brown with a medium sized beige head, some lacing. Aroma of malts, caramel, sugar, chocolate and earthy. Flavor is sweet malts, caramel, dark fruits with a bitter finish 
A nice double.

This beer has a beautiful brownish red color. It has a sweet caramel aroma it has a rich complex somewhat sweet flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Darker copper pour, with a thick and lasting head. Perhaps this is an interesting version of this style. Yeasty, slight woody, lasting bitter finish. Impression is kind of... warm, brown sugary, faintly bitter. Much more going on as it warmed up. Enjoyable but... wanted more going on.

Would I drink again? yes.

Would I order again? maybe.
The aroma is earthy, pepper. The appearance is hazy, deep amber, white head. The flavor is sweet fruit, light pepper. The finish is light is light pepper, fruit. Medium in body. Decent.
Dark roasty malts with that wonderful beligan yeast in the background. A sweetness is present that is almost sugary. Carbonation was pretty mild with a dry finish.
Bomber bottle. Reddish dark brown with off white head. Aroma of bread, syrup, vinous, liquorice and a creeping bitterness

22oz bottle, dark brown color, with some reddish highlights, and a pillowy beige head. Nice yeasty fruity nose of raisin, fig, date esters, with some raisin pie, apple sauce, chocolate chip cookie dough, plum juice, toasted, caramelized, biscuity, chocolate malt accents and a toffee, date squares, sponge toffee, candi sugar, grahams cracker, brown sugar note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a nice sweet dark dried fruit, yeasty, toasted, caramelized, biscuity, chocolate malty character, with some dry raisin, fig, date, light chocolate bar, date square, toffee, spicy, faint por liquor, raisin pie flavours, with a candi sugar, molasses, raisin glosette candyish undertone, leading towards a warming, yeasty, doughy, spicy, dark dried fruitiness, chocolatey, lingering faint coffee, toasted, caramelized, biscuity, chocolate maltiness finish.

Pours a dark copper color with a thick khaki head. Yeast, malt, brown sugar, caramel and raisin aroma. Brown sugar, plumb, raisin, yeast, malt caramel and bubblegum flavors. Medium light body and raisin finish.

Sweet, dark fruit aroma; a little tartness. Malty flavor: Sweet, caramel, dark sugar, raisin-like fruit, biscuit. Yeast flavor is relatively mild: bubble gum, pepper, herbal. Also some tart flavor... Low carbonation for a Dubbel.
Mahogany pour with an off white head. Spiced malt aroma. Strong malt spiced liquor flavour. Earthy tangy finish. Nice brew.

Dark cola brown with a pillowy crown floating on top. Aroma and flavour is lighter then I was hoping for but all the right elements seem to be here. Yeasty banana with elements of red wine and oak. Very sweet in the front and has a lingering bitter in the finish. Brown sugar really shows up in the brew the warmer it gets, and the warmer the brew gets the more I like it. Brew gets fuller and stronger the longer I let this sit. No real complaints about this beer except for the fact it didnt wow me.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2013 Draft at Farmers Cabinet. Poured very dark but showed as a clear ruby red under bright light. Pungent cherry sour at the bottom but brighter brown fruit at the top. Rotted bing cherries. Bit of a watery double.

Draft at Stags Head. pours kinda ugly dull brown with sweet and spicy nose. Tastes of caramel, plums, red grapes, woody, peppery, brown sugar, and mild alcohol finish. kinda odd zesty palate that was enjoyably different.

Medium brown/mahogany pour with a tan head that leaves a light blanket of lace. Brown sugar, plums, smoke, significant amounts of smoke, something woody as well, on the nose. Strong toffee on the palate with some cheap caramel (those little Kraft blocks of caramel from Halloweens gone by) and dark fruit notes with a solidly spicy finish.
Not exactly true to style but a pleasant brew nonetheless.

22. Pours an opaque dark eggplanty brown with a dense and creamy tan head that sticks around for a while. Some CO2-ish notes on the nose along with plenty of dark pitted tree fruit. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Caramel, plums, dark brown bread, and a bit of aluminum on the mid palate. Tinny finish...take away the metallic and CO2 notes and this would be a world class beer.

22 oz bottle. Pours a reddish amber with a light haze and a rather off-white head. Molasses and dark fruit, caramel aromas. Flavor similarly mixes raisin, red grape, molasses, and caramel, adding some distinct red apple. Mild alcohol sensation as it finishes. This is a pretty good one with clean, tasty flavors.

Pours a clear mahogany color with a small, light tan head. Lots of candi sugar up front on the nose, molasses, caramel, dates, and plums. Nice toasted sweet malt note, very earthy taste, brown sugar, and dark fruit. Very smooth, not too sweet, and Im digging the kind of burnt sugar taste.
Well done dubbel. Nice aroma of molasses and dried fruit. Pours dark brown with oily head. Taste is spot on dubbel, woody, fruity, sweet. Maybe I wont miss Belgium so much after all.

New Beer Distributors, NY 650ml ($6.25): Pours mahogany with a tan head. Aroma is raisins, brandy, sugar, booze. Taste is sweet and fruity, but has a veritable hoppy undertone that gives it a substantial amount of bitterness towards the finish and aftertaste. Long lingering sugary aftertaste. Pretty good. Perhaps a little too sweet.

Bomber - pours dark amber and wont sneak up to bite my nipple. Nose is fruity like repressed republicans. Flavor adds what the moralist 19th century bourgeoisie refused to enjoy: sugar and chocolate amongst other luxury items. sweet like smeared squashed caterpillars on my toast. THE POWER OF BEER! metallic aftertaste.
Best double around, very balanced and aromatic! I have had very few doubles better than this while over in Belgium.

Bottle @ Epic Beer Fest Denver 2013. Pours a dark brown appearance with a beige head. Toffee, light anise, tootsie roll, chocolate, a bit fruity aroma. Mild banana, anise, brown sugar, raisin flavor. Not too bad but nothing special.
January 2012. Bottle. Dark amber color with a white head. Aromas of malt, spice, brown sugar and fruit. Good balance and the finish really shows the spice.

On tap at Joe Canals West Deptford.
Appearance: The body is clear with a deep copper to mahogany hue, the head is tan and creamy, though its short.
Aroma: Slightly malty with brown sugar and slightly medicinal cherry, but also a faint gasoline aroma.
Taste: This is a big and malty double with a deep slightly medicinal cherry flavor on the intro and lots of brown sugar and raisins. The finish is spicy, perhaps cinnamon or cloves.
Palate: Medium to thick with soft carbonation.
Overall: I really enjoy the complexity of this, but the aroma is a bit off-putting. I enjoy this though and would consider buying it in the Winter.

10oz snifter on tap at Dilly Deli, $4.25. Mostly clear but very dark brown / red color. Some minimal to thin lightly khaki head. Just a few loose bits of lace. Smooth, lighter, lightly soft carbonation. Bigger body. Lightly dry in the finish. Some dark fruit. Light hint of coffee, light bit of roast malt character. Moderate sweet taste. Light bitter. Light alcohol warmth. Very light spice. Nice American dubbel.

Bottle. Pours a quite hazy and very dark brown color with almost no head on it. Nose is malty and sweet with the sugary elements coming through. Taste is very sweet with just a bit of that Belgian yeast coming through. Not my style.
Smells of raisins and figs. Taste is very sweet, very nutty, oaky and sweet finish. yeah, weirdly nutty.
Reddish brown with yellowish head. Aroma is fruity caramel. Fast is raisin, wine and grassy. Very nice.

Pours a clear dark reddish brown with an inch or so of rich yellowish head.  Aromas are primarily barnyard yeasty bits.  Some malt backbone with red wine, molasses character.  Funky finish.  Pepper.  I like a little more richness/sweetness in my doubles.

Appearance was clear red caramel honey gold with diminishing creamy tiny off white head, no lacing. Aromas are complex array of deep fruits,caramel, chocolate, hints of biscuit malts, estery yeasts and port like alcohol present. Taste was sweet plum, raisin, port, hints of pine, spices and grass with fruity yeasty warming alcohol. Palate was soft creamy silky CO2 with medium-full body, then long warming  deep fruity Belgian yeasty glorious finish. Just a touch to much alcohol, it would be stunning.

August 15th, 2012 - Most markets separate the fancy beer collections into two segregated groups. The first belongs mostly to American made craft beers, sometimes mingling the single bombers with the colorful bricks and block designs of stacked six-packs. The second section belongs to the foreign and imported beers, usually of Belgian origin, and sometimes the odd American beer whose price tag better fits with the Belgian stuff. And heres my problem. On a tight budget, I feel like I can get more beer for my buck when I go for the domestic craft brewers. This means Ive spent a lot more time with hops than I would like and a lot less time with Belgian flavors than I would prefer. Brother David comes to the rescue, delivering many of those core Belgian yeasty flavors at an affordable price point. The Dubbel from Anderson Valley pours a murky deep brown, emitting an aroma with a light soy sauce scent, ample molasses and brown sugar, a pinch of nutmeg and a general sweetness that makes me feel like Im smelling the dessert cart at a fancy restaurant. The flavor pushes forward onto the palate with tons of alcohol, broken up by deep soy sauce tanginess and the deep, dark sweetness of fig in the back. Broadly this is a woody and deep flavored beer, but the alcohol is a little too dominant, and it interferes with the grander potential thats lurking in the background noise. This might be a good candidate for aging, but since I have just one bottle, I have to evaluate it as is. Again, having those Belgian tastes at a price that doesnt make my wallet and my heart wither is nice, but its also an indication of what that extra money goes towards - the real deal.

One finger of head on a dark copper colored body.
The aroma is caramel, candy and bread. 
The taste is moderately malty sweet and balanced nicely with an underlying bitterness. Plum and dense wheat bread too.
The texture is smooth with moderate carbonation and heavy body.
I like it. A solid dubbel style ale.

Deep burgundy brown with a nice fluffy head.  Aromas of ripe plum, caramel, prunes,black licorice and a touch of sherry.  Davids smooth, creamy body imparts flavors of sherry, raisins, brown sugar, and a slight hit of acidity.  Finish is clean and slightly sweet.  This is one of the best American takes on a Belgian Dubbel I ever had.  Just wish the body was a bit more dry.  Pare with strong cheese: Blue or Gouda be rockin my boat.

On tap at Pony with James, Streets, Andy & Jenn 10/31/2012. Brownish-red pour with a tan head that lingers around the edge of the glass. Red tinge. Sugary malt aroma which is almost tart and very nice. Palate is medicinal Belgian yeast with some sugar and spice. Short legs.
Pours a clear ruby. Aroma is yeast and tin, some sweetness. Taste is OK some sweetness, fruit, but not overly flavorful.

Bottle. Ruby-copper pour with a tall, foamy tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, sweet malt, candi sugar, yeast notes, and caramel. Taste is sweet malt, dark fruits, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, caramel, dark bread and soft chocolate notes. Body is medium with a moderate, bubbly carbonation and mild warmth from the alcohol. Finishes with more caramel, sweet malt notes, dark bread, yeast, dark fruits, soft cocoa and cake notes. Rather tasty!

650ml bottle pours amber in color with a 2 finger white head that leaves some decent lacing on the glass.  Aroma is dark fruits and caramel with some mild yeast.  Taste is a fruity and malty sweetness with some  yeasty notes and a light hoppy bitterness.  Medium bodied with a moderate carbonation.  A very well done Dubbel style ale that is definitely recommended for a great tasting experience.

Single bottle purchased from a Utah State Liquor Store in Kimball Junction, Utah on 11/02/2012. Colour: Dark brown/red mix with low fizzy white head. Nose: A cherry bomb blast off the first whiff. Notes of banana, spinach, rotting wood. More cherry. Taste: Medium sweet, light bitter, medium sour. A salty rush encompasses very basic sugar, over-ripe fruit (banana, pear) strong malt. Although I am a fan of Anderson Valley, this one is along the lines of some craft brewing (and society as a whole) in the USA, being overly sugar dominant and losing focus on the essentials.
22 oz bomber from Binnys in Chicago. Pours clear reddish amber slightly small off-white head. Aromas of sweet malst and. bready yeast. Flavours of cherries, dates, raisins and brown sugar.

small frothy off white head. fair lacing. mostly diminishing. flat thick dark reddish-brown body. aroma: alcohol, red wine, wood, mild coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, heavy malty. if: moderate sweet light bitter. ff: light bitter sweet, salty; long duration. palate: light medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, metallic moderate alcoholic finish. aroma frutas secas, luzes rubi na cor, toques salgados permanecem até o final, forte aquecimento alcoólico, diferente da média, pois o dulçor não é tão forte, sabor frutado após ganhar temperatura, 120 s

Strong aroma has earthy, malty and caramel notes with a hint of hops. It pours a dark coppery brown with a thick and rather persistent light tan head that leaves minimal lacing. Scrumptious flavor has caramel, malty, nutty, earthy and subtle maple syrup notes - not too sweet, very slightly hoppy.  Rich texture has plenty of tingle and fizz, smooth yet lively - very satisfying. An excellent party to Brother Davids Tripel.

Great. First the aroma is dry fruit esters, dark leather and wild yeast. Appearance is dark brown, filtered light head.  Taste is wild yeasts, slight sour, rich full body, and mouthfeel, lots of big flavors, banana, cereal, dough, rasin, palate is clean but grainy and leftover esters. Overall its complex, full, rich malty goodness that was made just like the monks do up in Belgium. Super yummy, try it

A-- Poured a dark brown but settled a light cola color. Very short lived head that went to film quickly. Some head retention but not a lot. ABV streaks on the sides of the glass.

S-- Grape, raisin, some dark fruits, and a touch of bubble gum. Smells a lot like Chouffe Nice. A little bit of an alcohol smell but not real big. Mostly grape and raisin.

T-- Raisin, red grapes, a little bit of sour cherry, and prune. Still a bit of bubble gum taste to this.

M-- At times a over carbonated and at times almost perfect. Front reminds me of Chouffe Nice a lot and the back is closer to a dubble, with the bread and cherry. To me a little bit of a cross between a Strong Dark Ale and a Dubble. Not bad but not great.
Pours brown/red with a tan head.  Aroma is caramel and booze.  Taste is malty, sweet caramel with a boozy finish.

Amber in color with a khaki colored head.  Nose is really quite boozy.  Some dark fruits, brown sugar, toffee, and mild spice.  A little bit of banana and bubblegum, too.  The flavor isnt bad as far as the sugar and sweetness goes, good date, fig, and raisin fruit notes, mild banana, and a hint of spice.  But the beer is just far too boozy to really be all that enjoyable.
Taken from old notes. Nose of caramel malts with some sweet and sour notes. Taste is sharp with a hop bite that fades into a boozy, sweet finish.
This is a nice full-bodied ale. Not much head for a double. It is a little bit on the bready side, with flavors of grapes, oranges and chocolate.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2014 650 ml bottle. Pours a red brown with medium head. Aromas of caramel and roasted malt. Similar flavors with additional notes of dark fruit and spice. Sweet start with bitter acidic finish.
Pours a dark red-brown with a 2-fingered tan head.  Smells of read, caramel, spice.  Taste is sweet and bitter, hint of the candy sugar, malty, small hop presence.

Dubble? More akin to a Quad - this is big, rich and forgivingly Belgian. In fact the yeast is prominent in this one. Lots of dark fruit, figs, prunes etc with a good dryish finish. Not overly complex like the best Quads, but  a pleasure to drink.

Maybe i drank too many wines tourring Napa Valley today, but after looking forward to a really nice beer, this was a disappointment. Aroma was faint, but complex with hints of dates and licorice.  Tastes were subtle currants, raisins, and a hint of banana. Just not as strong a taste as I desire in this style of beer.

22oz bomber poured into my Chimay Trappist glass. Pours a dark nut brown with a very thin ring of quickly dissipating white head. Aroma of caramel, banana, dark fruits and toffee. Taste is light sweet. Caramel, dark fruits, banana and Belgian sugar. Medium bodied with a sticky texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, awesome. Even better that I got it on the discount rack for $3!

A nice caramel malt odor was the first impression. This was followed by the same in the taste. Not overly carbonated with very little head. Good deep brown color accompanied with an average palate. Good and pleasant to drink while relaxing for the evening. However, not unique enough to make it exceptional. Was difficult for me to find, so if you are from Texas and see it, pick one up to try.
Pours a deep reddish-brown with a good off-white head that dissipates quickly.  Good, mild aroma that somehow reminded me of banana bread.  Good flavor and medium body.

On tap. Pours a dark cloudy brown with a creamy off white head. Aroma is sweet malt, dark fruits, caramel and spices. Taste is also fruity, some caramel, spices and hints of nuts leading to a fruity and light bitter finish. Really nice.

What a kick up from the pedestrian Tripel. Beautiful clear brown with an off white head. The nose is all dates and figs with a hint of caramel. High carbonation leading to a great mouthfeel. Long, fruity finish. Paired with Chimay Abbey cheese.

bottle.  clear light brown with no head.  brown sugar, toffee, nougat, raisin and other dark overly ripe fruits in aroma.  very light bodied for the style.  flavors of dark fruits and sweet brown sugar with some banana.  not their best work.

Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma contains some toffee, caramel, and spices. The flavor is quite malty with some nuttiness, caramel, and toffee. The palate is a bit thin but thats all good. Some booze in the finish. Overall not bad for a US made tdubbel.

22oz bottle. Pours a reddish brown with a light tan head that fades fast. Big apple aromas waft off the top immediately. A bigger sniff reveals a bit of smoke and cinnamon. Taste is big and malty. The apple comes through but is overwhelmed by dark fruits and a bit of oak and a big aftertaste of smoky malts. A bit of dry sweetness lingers on the tongue.
Flaske 6 fl. oz.  på Bishops Arms, Kiruna 28 Mar 12. Mørk amber på farge. Hickory. Lavt luftig skum. Aroma dominert av plommer. Smaken mandler & plommer. Syrlig ettersmak.

Bomber. Clear, deep amber liquid with medium off-white/light tan head. Smells of dark fruits, caramel, toffee, banana, belgo yeast esters and biscuity malt. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of dark fruits and caramel. Light to medium bodied with OK carbonation. A bit watery actually. Overall, OK dubbel, but it has got nothing on the better Belgian examples.

660ml bottle shared at Bishops Arms Kiruna. Hazy, dark amber body with a reddish shade. Patchy surface. Aroma of dark and dried fruits, noticeable alcohol. Sweet malts, dark plums and prunes in flavour with a hint of mould cheese. Long-lived bittersweet ending sustained by alcohol. Full bodied. Nice, 28.04.2012

Bottle. Kind of on the imperial side of the Dubbel category. Pours with a very clear mahogany to very deep bronze hue, clear with reddish highlights, medium to slightly smaller head for the style. Off-white head doesnt last fully. Some alcohol/viscous legs rise above any lace and bat it down slightly. 

Strong and complex aroma balancing malt and yeast. A plethora of dark fruits, plums, cherries, dates, raisins. Some pear, very light isoamyl acetate as well. Persimmon. Some nutty and light chocolate (fudge notes), caramelized and brown sugars. Light tangyness and low phenol. A bit of a floral, earthy presence that might be a bit of hop.

 Flavors show the alcohol. Warm, malty. A bit of an odd/too apparent nutty/toasty/earthy/lightly tannic character going on (at first, but it seems to fade (or get overrun by alcohol) as it warms). Big dried fruit character, dates, figs, raisins, persimmon. Lightly rummy and vinous, some floral notes. Malt character once warm is rich in a toasted malt way. Light musty quality from the yeast to go with the dark fruit esters. Very slight phenol presence. Medium sweetness through to the finish which is dry. Slight mineral character felt on the tongue in the finish. Lightly leathery. Some balancing bitterness and alcohol last through the aftertaste.

Big and warming! Fuller body with medium-high carbonation. Pretty dry on the finish which is nice.

Overall a pretty good interpretation of the style. In California fashion, this is a big version of the style with slightly more hop character than I am use to in the style. Still tasty. One problem I seem to find with American made dubbels are that they finish way too sweet. This one thankfully follows a more traditional model with dryness.
Poured from bottle a chocolate brown with a light tan head. Aroma of sweet fruits and some caramel. i did like the triple better than the double.
Deep amber like color in the glass. It had an aroma of apples, honey and mild alcohol. The taste has some sweet malts with banana. Fairly smooth with a good finish.

pours brown with no light coming through.thin white head that quickly dissapates.aroma is malt,raisins and dough,flavor completely matching the aroma and alchohol is very well hidden.medium body and heavily carbonated with a fizzy mouthfeel.has a bitter finish but not unpleasant.decent double but could use a little more aroma and flavor profiles going on.a slight improvement would make this beer damn good.perhaps a little spice?says spice in the introduction but im not getting much for an abbey
Aroma a bit mediciny flavor of dark, over right fruit, a bit of sour finish.

Pours a light brown with little carbonation. Characteristically yeasty and malty, with some stone fruit and a thin mouthfeel. A bit sweet. A good double, but lacks the sophistication I get from the best Belgians.

22 oz bottle. Pours a chocolate brown with a vanishing white head. Aroma is dominated by sticky dark fruit, some raisin and plums. The taste is smooth and creamy with sweet dark fruit. Medium body with good carbonation.

655 ml bottle. Deep brown colour. Liquid caramel. Sweet caramel flavours. Alcohol in the nose. Very malty and sweet. Lots of caramel, did I mention caramel? Quite bitter to balance. A little over the top in my opinion.
Dark brown, bit of redness to it, with minimal head that dissipates slowly. Smell is sweet, malty, a bit of fruit. Tastes of sweet malts, some dark fruits, and not much in the way of hops.

Poured to glass from a bomber....dark amber color, not very cloudy if at all. Light tan head with a descent amount of lacing. Aroma was somewhat so so...picked up some hops and booze from the bomber. When I poured it into the glass the aroma was less of the flavors I picked up from the bomber. Taste was bread, raisin, licorice, and clove. Medium body with some lacing on the glass....not too bad of a dubbel, would try again.
I did not dislike it, but it is not my favorite beer. It is very close to the limit of sweetness I tolerate.

[4175-20111203] Tap. Not much aroma. Clear, dark amber body with a quick foamy off-white head. Boozy sugary malt flavour has a lingering cloying sweet spicy grain. Medium-full body. Average, not really in the mood for it. (6/3/6/3/13) 3.1
(@ Coles, Buffalo, NY)

Glad I finally got around to this.  Sweet, yeasty aroma with a bit of barnyard funk.  Dark brown pour with amber highlights - and, interestingly, a little pink in the foam.  Brother David makes a malty and complex dubbel (in AVs solar-powered brewhouse).  Notes of bourbon, lemon, brown sugar, dark chocolate, and honey.  It finishes with alcohol warmth and a dry hop tingle.

Pours a clear garnett color with a full light tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit and a pleasant sourness.  Taste is sweet roasted malt, licorice, plums and spices.  Interesting.  A little busy, but certainly well balanced.  Alcohol warmth evident after the swallow.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of caramel, nutty and a hint of milk chocolate, moderate cooked orange for the hops, moderate dough for the yeast with raisin, toffee, brown sugar and nutmeg. Head is small, fizzy, light tan with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Flavor starts moderately to heavily sweet, and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic and only faintly bitter. Palate is medium, a little slick with a soft carbonation. Nice and smooth aspects to this Abbey Dubbel which makes it both savory and easy drinking.

pours hazelnut brown with minimal head, ringed retention, show moving lacing, super micro CO2, scattered slow moving CO2 streams. Dark malty nose with a bit of scotch. Strong brown sugar up front, 7/10 sweetness, mixed with deep malts and an ethyl alcohol backdrop. Slightly dark fruity. Silky carbonation and buttery mouthfeel. Low-medium complexity, med-high depth, excellent carry, medium-long length, decent carry. Potent high ABV beer, but not complex enough for me to try again.

22oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours brown with lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, brown sugar, some caramel malts, and some floral hops.  Flavor about the same.  Average texture.  A good beer.

Clear dark ruby, with an unlasting head. Nice malty aroma with a touch of booziness, burnt caramel, and some eccentric Belgian yeastiness. Taste is full and big, with some big yeasty fruit esters, some soy sauce, earthy chewy sweet malts, burnt caramel, and some more boozy esters, though not much heat. Nice warming tones of cherry and fig, but lots of earthyness.

Appearance: browns  soft leather and old shoes. Khaki head fades fast into a collar of bubbles and foam. Lingers as a patch of film, swirling with a lingering bready blanket.

Nose: spice, raisins, and dried plums. Pumpernickel raisin bread. Plum skins, red grape skins. Musk, apple seeds, and pomace for some nice dry tannins. Saddle bags.

Palate: interesting. Dark fruits grab the middle  prunes, figs, dates. Hint of licorice root, treacle. Brown sugar and cinnamon. Maraschino cherries and pineapple. Brown breads  pumpernickel and raisin especially. Grows sweeter as it warms up  almost saccharine.

Final Thoughts: a bit scattered and messy. Okay but not really together for a respectable double/dubbel. Ive tasted better from Anderson Valley.

Bottle shared at the 6th annual Richmond Industry Gathering, 11/27/11. Pours a clear amber color with a thin frothy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of brown sugar, citrus hops and a leafy finish. The taste is toffee, brown sugar and a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied.

This beer was excellent. It was so good I practically drank the whole thing before I rated it. Spicy, caramel, toasty, rich, smooth, perfect. I was going to rate this lower and then I asked myself where does this beer not measure up?  Its awesome and I will make it a regular. If I had to give it a knock I would say that It would be more appealing cloudy in appearance like Chimay.

Bottle like the picture.  Appetizing frothy brown head dissolving in less than a minute with fast sheet lacing over a strong pekoe tea-colored body.
Aroma is alcohol, citrus peel, ceral, dough, clove, coughdrop, licorice, and raisin.  Would be better without the alcohol distraction.
Taste is salty then quite bitter like alcohol but carrying a woody aroma.
Palate is a long bitter finish.
This isnt a beer I can relax with.  Wont buy this one again.

Surprisingly good Belgian from Anderson Valley. Light aroma, but it gets better once you start drinking it. Moderately complex malt character with slight hints of raisin, plum and clove. Finishes with a slight alcohol and yeast bite on the palate. This is a nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish-brown with a lasting beige head.  Sweet aroma with notes of caramel and spices.  Flavor is sweet malts and caramel with some spices thrown in.  Maybe a hint of hop bitterness at the finish.  Decent, but almost too sweet.

Nose is dried dark fruit, brown sugar, caramel.  Appearance is clear, dark reddish, with a fine thick long lasting head with good lacing and nice retention.  Candy and booze greeted me at the same time with this, plus some burnt malts and a bit of dark chocolate.  Dry clean finish.  Very nice, though I prefer the more subtle Belgian models I certainly wouldnt turn down  a glass of this and if I see it again, Ill buy!

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear medium to dark amber colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, burnt malt - caramel - brown sugar, moderate yeasty, light candy sweet, light metalic. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, spicy yeast, burnt malt, caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20111001]
Bottle @ Autumn Tasting, Ulfborg 2011. Pours ruby amber with a creamy white head and lacings. Sweet nose of nuts and caramel. Very malty. A bit of fruit. Medium bodied. Warmth from alcohol.
Clear red with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish with warming alcohol. 011011
Bottle. Dark amber/brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, yeast, caramel and fruit. Flavour is malt, yeast, dried fruits, caramel, medium sweet, little toffee and a little bitter.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are molasses, caramel, fruits, malt and hops.

Fantastic outing from Anderson Valley, one of my favorites and most consistent breweries from the west.  Pours a dark amber with a frothy, but thin, tan head.  Consistently bubbly body.  Aroma is sweet with a light, plum essence.  Taste is smooth, a tad sweet with a light spice.  I am yet to try the triple, but I think this is on par with the double and triple from Ommegang

Bottle.
Deep amberish mahogany, light brown head. 
Fruity, spicy, yeasty nose, oranges, cloves, some chocolate. 
Dryish, full bodied, medium bitterness. 
Spicy, fruity, quite yeasty taste, cloves, chocolate. Thins out quickly, leaves bitter alcoholic finish. (2011-07-01)

A reddish brown ale with a thin moka head. In aroma, a pleasan vinous malt with treacle, honey maple, light oxidation notes, but acceptable. In mouth, a nice smooth burned caramel, treacle, molasses, vanilla fudge, very nice well blended. Probably 2 years old. Tasted June 18, 2011.

Cellared for 2+ years.  Pours a dark, clear, brown with hardly any head.  Aroma of caramel, malt, and yeast with some sweetness.  Taste is slightly sweet, with some fruit.  Slightly bitter and earthy finish/aftertaste.

Small beige head doesnt last. Clear dark brown body. Caramelly bubble gum aroma with earthy chocolatey notes. Sweet roasty earthy alcoholic taste with bubblegum notes. Fullish body. Sharpish, hot mouthfeel. Dryish hoppy bubblegum and alcohol aftertaste with earthy peppery butter notes. Didnt really like this. Too hot and harsh, and too sweet and heavy. (0.65l bottle, La Trappe, San Francisco.)

From tap at RattleNHum. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted dark malty and yeasty, phenolic. Slight spiced, dry malty and light overripe fruity. Bitter and caramelish. Dry and herbal into the finish. Ends slight bitter.

Sampled at Brewery Creek U.S. event @ VCBW. Pours a very deep ruby tinged dark brown with moderate off-white head. Aroma of sweet malts, brown sugar, raisin, plum, and some yeast. Flavour is sweet with bready malts, caramel, bourbon, some dark fruit. Noticeable hops and a bit of chocolate toward the end. Good stuff.
Big apple juice flavor which is not uncommon with abbey dubbels. Good, but nothing that special. Kind of dull flavor.

This beer comes out a ruddy and rugged brown.  I went with a vigorous pour for this but still ended up with very little in terms of head.  Cloudy with some light carbonation.  Pulling the beer right out of the fridge, the aroma is very muted, with hints of raisin.  As the beer warms I get more hints of dark fruit, with figs and plums to go along with the raisin.  Theres some nice brown sugar sweetness in the background, almost like molasses.  Very enjoyable, just from smell alone.  Taste is very fruity, with that sweetness from the nose helping to balance things out in the end.  The alcohol in this beer certainly comes out, especially in the finish, but isnt obnoxious like others can be.  This beer is very well rounded and smooth, from beginning to end.  Very enjoyable.

Pours milk chocolate brown with a small off white head. Lots of dark fruits on the nose with a dash of chocolate. Some molasses in there as well. These dark fruits are at the forefront of the taste. Plums, cherries, raisins. Very earthy finish on this one. Good beer

bomber.  Pours dark, muddy, reddish brown color with very small, bubbly tan head.  Head could be bigger and more lively.  Complex aroma has lots of dark fruit tones, plum, raisin, fig, with a sweet, malty molasses / toffee aspect also going on with a faint hint of butterscotch.  Medium to full bodied but not thick, chewy, or syrupy feeling, low carbonation, perhaps too low for a belgian dubbel.  Flavor of raisin and fig with an earthy finish, reminding me of leaves and bark.  As it warms spices come out, both on the aroma and finish, pumpkin pie and fruitcake.  Abv hidden nicely.  Overall an unorthodox (or should I say american) version of a double, that certainly merits and a try with some interesting and unique things going on here.  Ultimately however I find it to be lacking in a couple of aspects to be a true model of the style.
Bottle: Poured a chocolate brown with a bubbly off white head. Thick sticky dark fruit some raisin and plums possible. The taste is smooth and creamy with sweet dark fruit.

Bottle. Great dubbel, never had Anderson Valley before. Pours a deep orannge tinged murky yellow with minimum off white head which fell away quickly. Biscuit and yeat in the nose with sweet malt. Average hopping with slightly grassy and citus notes. Enjoyed this one.
At a tasting, thanks David, bottle, pours dark reddish, almost without head, fruity aroma, characterless, and overall a very disappointing beer.

On tap at Anderson Valley in August 2009. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a burnt red bordering on brown with an off white head and a good amount of sticking lacing. Smell is cherries, chocolate, caramel, and nuts. A bit of spice. Taste brings forward some dark fruits as well as dark cherries and a bit of caramel and toffee. Mouthfeel is nice and coats the palate. Drinks quite well and is certainly one of the better American versions of this style that I have had.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-07-2010

Pours deep mahogany into a Trappist glass. Off-white head with little retention crackles and recedes to hug rim. Fruity pit fruit and biscuit aromas. Sweet dark pit fruit upfront turning to toasted nuts before a lasting earthy yeast finish.

Bottle served in a snifter at 55 degrees.  Ruby brown pour with a rapidly thinning off white head.  Banana and bubble gum nose with an intoxicating booziness.  Nice full mouthfeel.  Taste is malty, boozy, and quite good.   Theres a nice happiness that rounds out the flavor and keeps it from being too sweet.

12 oz bottle. Poured a ruby hinted brown; sizable creamy head. Aroma was not a standout for me; some yeast, dark fruit and maybe some brown sugar. Flavor was a little harsh for me; brown sugar, dark fruit, brown sugar, some spice.

A brown pour with a small tan head that dissipates quickly. Aromas got lots of dried fruit (raisins, plums) and some brown sugar notes, and a bit of roast malt background. The flavors a bit spicier, and fuller dark fruit flavors like cherry and fig. A bit of hop bitterness, but finishes sweet. Fairly thick mouthfeel.
Pours the color of tea.  Very nice tan head that held.  Strong earthy flavors of fruit, spices, and malt.  Would do better with a tad bit more carbonation but a very good double.
Bottle at a tasting 17th Dec. Typical of the style, hints of fruits and roasted malts through the aroma. Much the same in the taste, with the cherry, stonefruit, roasted malt being dominant.

On tap @ Rattle N Hum.
Brown/ruby and clear with very little head. Pretty typical belgian dubble aroma, fruity, cherry and banana, bubblegum, yeasty. Medium to full bodied, caramel malty notes come out more on the palate, get a touch of the alcohol (9%). Nice fruity finish. A solid dubbel.

A dark brown pour with a light brown head and lace. A brown sugar/molasses with rich sweet malt, raisins or dates. A very caramelly beer with a good bitter. Dried fruit in the flavor as well. Good carbonation for the style. Drinks like it smells. abv covered up pretty good to me.

Pours light red brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma is full of dark and light fruits; raisins, plums, grapefruit. But also includes a distinct yeast character and some brown sugar. Flavor is a bit bold for a dubbel but has a nice and complex fruit backbone with a slight balance of hops and other textures.

Clear reddish brown amber with thing lite brown head. Smells Dark fruits, raisins, prunes, brown sugar, yeasts. Taste is mildly sweet plums, golden raisings, brown sugar, bready yeasts & hops. Solid medium body with lite but zesty carbonation, medium alcohol warmth, decent hop bite and good dryness. A very good brew with nice complexity, alcohol well hidden, fruits are up front with nice balance of yeasts, malts and hops. Would not turn one down.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2010 Poured from a 22 oz bottle.  Pours an auburn hue with minimal head.  Aroma of bread yeast and raisin.  Taste of malt, brown sugar and raisins.  Tastes very similar to Chimay Blue and Lost Abbey Lost and Found.  Great Belgian.

The aroma of sweet resiny malts like a typical dubbel. T he Belgian style ale pours darky malty amber with a decent tan creamy head. The flavorsof the malts with sweet and a bit of leather and soy sauce. The medium body lets it drink smooth even though the ABV seems a bit high.

Bomber pours brown with loose mocha head. The modest aroma emits mostly apple with lesser supporting notes of dates, figs and some caramel. The taste is pretty smooth with a mix of brown sugar, red apples, dark sweet grapes, some yeast spices and a thin layer of caramel.

Tap @ Baileys Taproom...  Poured a deep burgandy with a khaki head.  Cloves, lots of yeast spices.  Oak, light seafood.  Thick foamy palate.   Dark fruits like plums and figs to offer a mild sweetness.  Vanilla, cotten candy, bubblegum yeast flavors towered the finish.

Dark red amber with decent, creamy, tan head / Nose of sour malt and caramel / Medium to full body, some sweetness and stickiness, a touch thin, with good balance and fair finish / Straight forward flavors of sour malt, caramel, coffee, and brown sugar / A lackluster effort for AV.
At a tasting: brown sugar, honey, toasted caramel, some rasines, marmalade, a bit of dried fruits, light hoppy bitterness al the way through, some alcoholic notes, nice.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a thin off white head, of short duration, over a clear light copper brown (SRM 18) body.....nose is sweet malts with dried fruits (cherry, plum)....taste is sweet malts, with dominant dried fruits, cherry, raisin, plum, finishing  with mild sweetness....mouth feel is medium with a bit of alcohol heat, carbonation light to medium. This is a very rich, malty beer. The complexity of the malt back bone is quite lovely. It is more of a Doppelboch than a Dubbel in its sweetness, alcohol, and flavor, aroma characteristics. BJCP 6/3/14/4/6

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks David Cohen. Clear deep reddish brown. Aroma of malt, brown sugar, caramel and dark fruits. Sweet malty flavor with fruits, caramel, a bit of biscuits, light grainy hints and a dry, slightly alcoholic finish. Medium-bodied.

Bottle. Pours dark coppery red with a dense tan head that lasts well. Aroma has notes of toffee, berries, candy sugar, yeast and dark fruit. Flavour almost mirrors the aroma although the dark fruit notes and the yeasty spiciness are more dominant. Mouthfeel is slightly oily with moderate carbonation and a lingering spicy, mildly sweet finish. Pretty good dubbel, ticks all the boxes but stops short of being a real standout.

Bottle.  Black wax.   Pours a nice dark brown with a beautiful tall creamy dense khaki head.  Nice lace.  Sweet, candi sugar and dark fruit aroma.  Nice, but a bit one dimensional, and a bit boring.  The flavor is very nice, but just a bit over the top.  Very sweet with a very pronounced candi note.  plenty of ripe dark fruits as well, including sweet purple grapes.  No flaws in the flavor, just seems to be turned up a notch to high.  Medium body with medium carbonation.  Overall: a solid beer that is only slightly misguided, IMO.
At a tasting, thanks David, pours deep red with a nice head, aroma of grapefruit, oranges, peach, mango and herbs, flavors metal with some orange, apricot and toffee, medium to full body.

At a tasting, many thanks David, smallish head, dark burgundy red colour, aroma of cherries, strawbeery and some jamminess, flavour of plums and cherries, but not enough malty backbone, sour bitter aftertaste with some dried fruits in the end, body a tad to light but still quite good.

Tasted from bottle.  Pours clear amber with a decent-sized tan head.  Nose is yeast, bread, candi sugar, and a hint of nuttiness.  Flavors are similar with a just a hint of hops and the nutty flavor coming through nicely.  The body is medium with heavy carbonation and medium malt finish.

Aroma is of raisin, rum, honey, and slight biscuit.  Slight tan head on a ruby red pour.  Very complex flavors, such as banana, brown sugar, bubblegum, and clove.  The body is full, texture is thick and oily, carbonation is average, finish long and sweet.  This is a very fruity and earthy beer with a good clean palate and the alcohol is well hidden.  I would recommend this for Belgian ale lovers.

Aroma: Spicy, citrus hops, rich sweet caramel malt, slightly nutty milk chocolate, a little bourbon and vanilla.
Palate: 
Flavor: Milk chocolate, caramel, nuts initially then, from the mid-palate through the finish, sour and toasted caramel flavors come through.
Comments: Moderately complex layers of aromas and flavor. Rich, desert-like. This is at least 1 year old and possibly 2.  Score range of 38-39.

West USA trip 2010. On tap @ Pizza Port Carlsbad. The aroma has caramel, sugar and honey, some hint of fruits. Clear, red-brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweet and has caramel and sugar mostly.

Murky dark brown pour medium carbonation yeast dark fruit brown sugar plum port aromas apetising tne flavours plum portwine yeast raisin relaxing ale good ibu smooth but sparkling malt aftertaste hop malt delight bitter that lasts nicely

Dark brown pour, low head and lace. Sweet musty fruit aroma. Very flat, some alcohol and caramel, with tart raisins. Very thick, phlegmy, and malty. Definitely a tangy apple/fruity flavor. Kind of gross, and very flat, just a hint of carb. Avoid.
Sweet peach with a cloying lingering chemical aftertaste.  Strong aroma of alcohol.  Mouthfeel is thick and appealing.  Its just the taste that falls short.

Draft in New Belgium glass at Toad in the Hole. Clear deep ruby with dissipating khaki head. Strong bready, yeasty notes arrive before more subtle raisin, toffee, and banana scents. Flavors are of plums, bread crusts, and the blackened parts of grilled foods. Finish is pleasingly dry and short. Not my favorite style, but I like this beer.

Pours a very deep, clear brown with a very nice garnet highlights. Almost no head is formed and it has a very low amount of carbonation. Aroma has a mild noble hops nose, toasted malt notes, lots of spicy clove and nutmeg, light notes of raisin fruitiness at the end. Flavor is much stronger than the nose alludes too. The flavor starts off with a strong apple, raisin and caramel combo that is reeeaaally good. This flows into fairly strong spicy note, lots of yeasty character in the middle, slight gingerbread presence toward the end with some alcohol, and finishes with a mild breadiness and light noble hops presence. Body is mild in density with a very smooth, slightly dry mouthfeel. Overall a very well done brew and one that will be around my house quite a bit considering the price is nearly half the cost if other higher end brews with half as much to drink. Very well balanced flavor and I wish the nose was just a tad bit stronger but it really doesnt detract from the brew (does get a slight bit stronger as it warms). I would be really curious to see how this would age after a few years.

Bottle. Pours a dark cherry color with a thin head. Light banana aroma, with a hint of bubble gum. Light cherries too, but not too strong. Nice mix in the taste. Light malt, but also a hint of citrus, as well as some vanilla. You can sense the alcohol as well. Very good beer from Anderson. I recommend.

Well this one is better than the tripel version just because it aint so dang sweet. Still, not a lot to it other than- well: With an aggresive pour got a little light tan to cream colored head and a little lace. Color is a clear mahoganey. Aroma is vanilla malt fruit. Flavor is the same and not awfully complex. Body is ok and so is carbonation. Finish is like flavor. I wont finish the bottle. (Only a few sips actually.) Be good for cooking not drinking. Meh.
Bottle, pours medium brown with a reddish tinge. Aroma of caramel malt. Flavour of caramel malts, toffee, brown sugar - more on the sweet side than the dry. Very nicely balanced.
Had some nice sweetness with caramel and banana notes, alcohol fairly apparent.... Not as good as the triple

22 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a cloudy brown color with a finger-thick tan head that sticks around for a while.  Notes of raisins, caramel malts, prunes, Belgian yeast, overripe aples, and what comes through as sort of Bavarian hops.  Medium-full bodied, with a yeasty mouthfeel and mild carbonation.  Alcohol is hidden.  I liked Brother Davids Triple just a little more than this, but still a nice beer.

This poured  a cloudy brown color with a beige head. Aroma was yeasty some dark candy sugar, very dry. Flavor was also very dry but with some belgian yeast character, some sweetness and hints of dark fruits
Pours a dark amber cola cola with minimal tan head. Aroma of chocolate, cherry, raisins and alcohol. Full bodied with minimal carbonation.  Smooth dry finish.

Bottled. Pours chocolate brown with a minimal tan head. It smells of caramel, toast and malt. Flavors include roasted malt, alcohol and brown sugar. Long lasting finish with hops chocolate and grass. Overall good but not great.

Poured dark amber and clear with an off-white head and flecks of lacing.  The aroma was yeast and citrus and raisin.  The flavor was cherry, raisin, citrus and yeast.  Thin to medium in body with a nice bit of alcohol that didnt feel out of place.
Pours a nice cola colored brown. Aromas of dark malts, fruit, and a touch of spice. Has flavors of chocolate, caramel, and a touch of wood.

Bomber into a trappist glass.  The pour is deep brown, ruby when held to the light, with a medium khaki head.  The aroma is sweet, boozey, and dark malt.  The flavor is somewhat one-dimensional with dark fruits, dryness, and plain roasted malt.  Not sure this one comes together too well.

Bottle. Poured a nearly opaque dark brown color with dim orange highlights. The head was a few fingers high and tan with decent retention.  Fruity and malty nose with distinct raisin, date, and molasses notes. There were also whiffs of milk chocolate, toffee, and brown sugar. Medium bodied and slightly sweet with the flavor following the aroma to a T.

Aroma is malty and fruity, with notes of raisins and prunes, followed by some pilsner and special B malt....with yeast and fruity esters. Flavor is similar to the aroma, with dark fruits prevalent followed by a malt finish. Decent Dubbel.

Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a deep brown color, with a moderately sized and long-lasting tan head.  Aromas of raisons, Munich malt, Special "B" malt, and prunes come through in the palate.  Abbey yeast esters also come through, showing some slight apple/pear character.  Finally, there is a slight note of bready/grainy pilsner malt.  The palate keeps the promises made by the aroma.  Deep Germanic malty flavors up front, followed by raisons, prunes, and esters.  Carbonation is mild to moderate; perhaps a little low for the style, but just right, in my opinion.  Alcohol is totally hidden.  Overall, this is an excellent version of the style.

Pour is very much like a cola.  A smallish tan head that leaves light but sticky lacing.  Quite a malty aroma with dark fruit.  Pleasant and substantial.  Flavor is also big malt with dark fruit.  Some rye and too much alcohol.  Very flavorful and an enjoyable beer.   One of those beers that after you finish it there is malt on your lips.  I happen to like such beers.
Pours reddish brown color with off white head. Aromas of dark fruits and molasses. Sweet raisin and fig flavors with Belgian candy sugar. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Medium brown color, decent carbonation. Aroma yeast and sweet dark fruit. Big dark fruit flavors, prune, plum, dark cherries.  Yeast and sweet malts, brown sugar.  Pretty well balanced, touch of alcohol on the end. Nicely done, quite drinkable.

$7 22oz Bomb-  This is my first Belgian-style ale that I have rated.  As a general rule, I stay away from these because Im not a big fan of "yeastiness" and other flavors associated with it.  Damn though, this is not a bad beer, I can actually drink this Belgian.  One thing: I like how Anderson Valley doesnt heat pasteurize their beer, but I cant stand the layer of yeast on the bottom that I cant stand having in my beer; I will not drink the last fifth because I mentally cant handle "dirty" beer.  Maybe nothing can be done about this side effect, but it is disgusting stuff to have in your beer--in my opinion.  Will not buy this beer again for $7, but it is good to expand beyond my comfort zone.

In short: A basic American take on the evasive Abbey Dubbel style.  Good.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Sent by (I think) by my summer Secret Santa.  Thanks a lot Secret SantaI mean Dave.
The look: Dark ruby body topped by a small beige head
In long: Nose is sweet and fruity, smelled like a raisin pie to me.  Taste brown sugar, raisins, baked dark fruits, almonds, some chocolate, some black cherries, some toffee, minimal woody hops contribution.  A little burnt malts sensation as if the beer was 80% toasted sugary caramelized malts and 20% totally burned malts.  All the desired dubbel flavours are there but somehow the whole thing just doesnt stand out.  I didnt find the mouthfeel very Belgian with its medium prickly carbonation.  As far as an American Belgian style dubbel is concerned this one is pretty decent..  But compared to true Belgian dubbel this is just average.  Most American brewery struggle to get with this basic Belgian style right.  I dont know why, and if theres one thing I dont understand, its everything.

Anderson Valley Brewing Company--Brother Davids Double Abbey Style Ale--Wax Seal--2005 Release--22 oz. Bottle--9.00% ABV--27 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Dubbel.  $4.99 Each.  Thin fizzy mild lace tan head.  Light sediment.  Clear red hint brown color.  Mild hop mellow Belgian toffee raisin front.  Complex mellow mild sweet Belgian Sugar toffee caramel toasted mild chocolate mild fruit ester body.  Smooth mild spice hint end.  Sampled 10/19/2008.
22 oz. Deep clear amber, thin head with decent retention. Spicy and fruity aroma. Balanced spice and malt flavors with a hint of bitterness. Thick, syrupy body with medium carbonation.
UPDATED: OCT 30, 2012 Sampled on BQ2010. Bottle. Pours a light brown body with nice white head.  Aroma is malts and some smokiness. Taste is sweet chocolate malts. Abrasive booze.

Dark brown pour with off white head that settles quickly.  Aroma of raisins, caramel malt.  Flavor is malt driven, raisin sweetness with a light fruit skin bitterness.  Nice mouthfeel.  Pretty pleasant to drink but, like most american dubbels, its pretty pedestrian and doesnt really do what its supposed to do.  Good thing it was kind of cheap, i guess.
Tried on Beer Quest 2010 with all the guys. This was number 7. Pours a dark brown. Clear. Little head. Aroma of sweet Malts and raisins. The flavor is nicely balanced with some caramel.

Bottle: Poured a deep brown color ale with a medium foamy head with average retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of lightly sweet caramel malt with some residual candi sugar. Taste is not overly complex with some bland caramel malts with some easily noticeable candi sugar. Body is a bit thin for style with OK carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Lacking some complexity and character with too much sugar.
Bottled.  Pour is light brown with off white head atop.  Slightly smokey and malt aroma.  Taste sweet malt and light cocoa.
Aroma of molasses, brown sugar, rum and malted chocolate. Appearance was murky brown with creamy head. Flavor matched the nose completely. Palate was lively. Another solid beer from Anderson Valley.

Bottle thats been kicking around far too long and has been taken to a number of places and then never consumed.  Its been to at least 3 different tastings, and BCTC and never got cracked into, so finally opened it tonight.  Pours a light cola brown with a thin yellowed beige head.  Loads of sweet caramel, a bit of oxidized cardboard, and a touch of chocolate and cherries.  Sweet, a bit boozey, and a lot of dark fruit.  Finishes really hot, lots of warming alcohol.  Unbalanced and tough to finish though.

~Aroma of chocolate, caramel, raisins, apple, and dried cherries. Perfumy. A lot going on in the aroma.
~Pours a dark amber with small off white head.
~The flavor is similar to the scent. Lots of maltiness. Slight smokiness.
~Creamy feel, full bodied, sweet finish.
~Excellent brew. Im just not a huge fan of sweet brews like this one. Well balanced and complex. Good dessert brew.

Tap at Lucky Devil.  Not bad AT ALL for a US Belgian.  Nose of banana and flour, nice dark brown color, flavor is banana, dark fruit, sweet dark malts, and a long slow finish.  If they started using Trappist yeast for this wed have a contender I think.  I was really pleasantly surprised.

poured ruby red oarnge with a dark eggshell colored head that fell pretty fast.  can smell apple and oarnges with alcohol breaking through. very dark in the glass with little light passing through from side to side.  thin lacing inside the glass as i spun the glass.  tastes lake wine grapes and tangerines with a bitter hoppiness to it and is not to malty.  slightly sweet with the tone of the alcohol setting in the middle of my palate.  medium bodied and with slighty malty aftertaste to it as it finishes.

Pours chestnut brown with no head. 

On the nose is an old attic wood chest smell, shelac maybe, with mold and cheap caramel candy aromas. 

On the palate is an off-toffy taste with a caramel chew flavor. Some unpleasant alcohol is present, and this finish is on the weak side for an Abbey. Easy to drink but not very appetizing. Worth trying if presented before you but not worth seeking out, especially at the premium price for the large waxed bottle. Disappointing.

Poured a very dark, almost cola-like cleare brown beneath a smallish tan head.  Aroma was delicate, fruits and spices combined.  Taste was quiate good, with some dark fruit and spices.  Solid mouth and nice finish, not too sweet.  High ABV was obvious but not in an unplesant way.  Pretty good dubbel for a non-Belgian.

cloudy brown, flimsy light beige head.
somewhat cloying aroma, theres malt and caramel with some cherries, raisings and alcohol.
flavor is more mild, with dark fruit, caramel, and a bit of chocolate. its a bit thin -- both in flavor and body. nice, slightly bittersweet, long finish.
Pours brown with a tan head.  Smells of dark fruit, syrup, molasses.  Tastes syruppy and sweet with some fruity hints on the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2011 12/30- bottle purchased in GR Michigan. 
Pours brown with dark red hue. Thin off white head. 
Chocolatey toffee aroma. 
Sweet taste. 
Bitter palate, chocolate, toffee, caramel. Tasty

Sample glass from the brewery.  pours a medium brown color in the glass.  hides the high alcohol content well with creamy sweet flavors of fruit and molases.

Bomber from Whole Foods (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark cola brown with mahogany highlights and thin white head that settles and dissipates quickly. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of ripe dark fruit, light floral esters, bread, yeast, brown sugar, caramel, some funkiness. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of caramel, ripe dark fruit, molasses, barnyard funkiness, hints of brown sugar, some light spice notes. Generally medium body with a sweet malty finish.

1 Pt. 6 FL OZ bottle poured into a chalice.  Poured chestnut brown with a tan head.  Sweet aroma with hits of soy sauce and a tangy Chinese dish plus fresh bread.  Rich flavors of caramel, syrup, faint chocolate and toastiness.  Fruity presence as well.  Good Dbl.

Bomber - Strong yeasty nose that is always reminiscent of baby food, or a fresh diaper, but there is definitely a baby quality here.  Sweet fruits of the darker variety, and just a slight hint of spice.  Sugar cookie dough matliness, but not over the top, this drinks quite simply and smooth.  Enjoyable, but not something that I would buy on a regular basis but a nice offering work picking up and trying once.

Draft at Blind Tiger (Greenwich Village, NYC).  Pours a clear ruby amber color with a thin beige head.  Sweet aroma of dried fruits, yeast, and spices.  Nice maltiness in the flavor followed by a slightly bitter finish.

Orange marmelade aroma with definite baby food pear notes. Hazy brown pour, headless. Maltier than expected, medium body. Relatively uncomplex flavor of fig and cookies. Perhaps cinnamon on the palate, but thats a stretch. Little complexity, but the alcohol is tastefully concealed.
I liked this one quite well. A solid Belgian double brew. Kicks like a horse, with all the usual flavors. Thumbs up on this one.

Bomber from Holiday Wine Cellar.  Pours a very deep ruby color bordering on dark brown with moderate off-white head.  Aroma of sweet malts, brown sugar, raisin, plum, and some yeast.  Flavor is sweet with bready malts, caramel, bourbon, some dark fruit.  Noticeable hops and a bit of chocolate toward the end.  Good stuff.

Bomber.  Clear, dark, reddish-chestnut brown in color, the body is crowned by a fleeting head of khaki colored foam.  Minimal, spotty lacing stays behind.  The aroma is standard dubbel fare, big fruity notes of raisins, prunes, and figs accompany brown sugar and molasses malts, with mild winter spices lending a bit of earthiness.  It smells slightly boozy, and some estery, doughy yeast adds some calming influence.  Flavors mirror the nose, mostly sweet and malty, with a big caramel, fig, and raisin presence.  The yeast is lightly peppery, and traces of nutmeg lend further, balancing depth.  Medium bodied and light to moderately carbonated, the semi-warm palate neither excites or offends.  Its a decent brew, pretty standard for a dubbel.

22oz bottle from Cairo Liquors, D.C. Dark red to brown pour, with a lively head and some decent retention. Very sweet malts in the nose, with a hint of cardamom also detectable as well as some dried fruit. Some hop crispness in the body, slightly sticky mouthfeel. A bit overdone as a dubbel, but not bad.

Bottle. Large creamy off-white head that mostly lasted. Fair display of lacework. Cloudy dark amber almost brown color. Aroma of toasted malt, nutty, caramel, mild bread, hint of yeast, dried fruity notes. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and light alcoholic texture. Moderated sweet flavor. Lingering nutty finish.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of spices, wood, slight candi-sugar, slight alcohol, malts, slight dry ripe fruits, and slight yeast.  Poured brown/deep orange in color with a small, tan/brown head that diminished but lasted around the edges.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of small particles throughout.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of tart fruits, malts, light caramel, candi-sugar, spices, dark ripe fruits, slight chocolate, figs, and a hint of tobacco.  Medium body.  Slick, then lightly chalky texture.  Average carbonation.  Sweet, dark ripe fruit, malt, and caramel finish is slightly chalky.  Cloyingly sweet.

22oz. Bottle from winter of 2007/2008.  Pours a dark mahogany color with a decent foam that laces nicely.  Aroma is subtle with hints of toffee and raisins.  Tastes pretty similar, a bit sweet with notes of Belgian yeast, dark fruits, candied sugar and caramel.  Palate is a bit thin and the carbonation level is medium. Finish is yeasty, dry and lingering.  A decent abbey style double.
UPDATED: JUN 4, 2009 Toffee and grassy flavors, sweet and heavily malty. Full body, Just not a style I like much.
Dark brown pour with a thin off-white head.  Dark fruit and malty aroma.  Similar flavor with a spicy twist.  Notable hints of toffee

22oz. bottle.  Malty, bready, sweet, fruity and lightly doughy aroma, some brown sugar and faint raisin, overall nose is pretty slight, though.  Clear deep red-brown color with an off-white, fine, subsiding head.  Lightly bitter and spicy to start, turning much sweeter and maltier before the fruity, drying, yeast-infused finish, features some lingering banana, cocoa and faint tartness.  Mouthfeel is smooth, lightly warming and low in effervescence, body is medium-full.  Relatively high in alcohol content for the style, but not correspondingly rich in flavor.

Smells tinny and slightly fishy, like a sardine tin (unappealing). Looks pretty, bits of ruby red when the light catches it. Tastes sweet and a little spicy with a lot of soft carbonation. Decent double but the smell bothers me.
slightly fruity, with a light malty presence with lots of character. the palate is thin but gives a sweet caramel that has some great  flavor.

The aroma is close to the style with sweet brown sugar, yeast, and dark fruits. The appearance is red brown with a nice head. The flavor is like the aroma with a touch of spice. The palate is average for the style. Overall its nice but nothing special.

Bottle from Brother Tuckers.  Dark brown pour, very small head.  Aromas of brown sugar, dark frutis, malt and maybe a hint of spice.  Flavor is fruity, toffee, yeast and some spice.  Not bad, not amazing.
incredibly yeasty aroma, very sweet taste. dark brown color which somewhat conflicts with the aroma. overall pretty nice.

Mahogany with a fairly thick cream head that dissipates quite quickly leaving no lacing.  Malty, sugary smell, not very complex.  Very sweet on first taste with a very slight bitter finish.  Doesnt have enough hops to balance the sweet.
Pours a dark nearly-black ruby with no head and a sweet, fruity (cherry) aroma. Flat an uninteresting fruity malt taste, some spice, nothing remarkable. Mild carbonation, thin body. Meh.

Pours clear ruby-brown, moderate beige head with moderate retention. Delicate nose of brown sugar, roasted grains, plums and apricots. Flavour develops dark fruit, yeast, roasted grains, hint of European hops. Relatively long, warm, roasty finish; moderately light mouthfeel with light carbo.

Solid head with staying power. Curiously, it does not recede in rocky fashion. Dark amber/light brown (with orange touches) color. Cloudy.

Relatively minor malty aromas, not as robust as other Dubbels. Some yeast, light caramel.

More sweet than I expected--closer to a barley wine in terms of taste. Theres the lightest of prickly hop in the background--not really balancing. Rich body with a decent level of carbonation. The aftertaste is sweet and short. Warming alcohol in the swallow but not noteworthy in the taste.

Pours a reddish brown with white head that fades.  Aroma is yeast, dark fruit, malt.  Taste is malty with dark fruit, caramel, bread, some spice, some warming alcohol.  Malty and hearty.  Finish is dry and a bit soapy, hopping minimal.  A pretty good dubbel.

Not much to look at, but this beer is one of the best Ive tried.  Very unique flavor that I keep coming back for.  Slightly sweet, hints of spice and banana, pleasant yeast flavor.  Very little bite.  The ETOH is a lot of fun!  Love this beer!

22oz bottle, served in a Chimay chalice a few minutes out of the fridge. Aroma is malty with dark fruits, cocoa, and vanilla. Dark red color with a wispy, short lived head and fairly gentle carbonation. Taste is dark fruits, spiced rum, a hint of banana, vanilla, and some warming alcohol. Mouthfeel is a little thin, additional carbonation would be appreciated. Enjoyable, well brewed, and solid but not one of the better examples of the style.

Deep brown in colour with a long lasting beige head, good retention and lacing.  The aroma is very malty - burnt as well, highly sweet, lots of brown sugar.  The flavour is very sweet, quite a bit of alcohol comes through, sugary, lots of malt and dark fruits.  Sweet mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long, very sweet and warming.
Very sweet and a little thin in the mouth but other than that its pretty good.
650ml bottle obtained in a trade with JohnnyJ, thanks John.
Opened on June 29, 2008.
No date.
A lovely sweet double - pleasant, yet not overly complex.  Rich and malty with a spicy Belgian yeastiness.  A good beer, but Im not sure if it is one Id want to order often or again.

Pours a deep amber with little head. Aroma is somewhat barleywinesque with the candy sugars and high alcohol aromas. Flavor is of said candy sugars, molasses, and a little maple. A little pruney to boot. And pretty yeasty/bready.  Mouthfeel is oily, as there is little carbonation. Viscosity medium. Overall I dont think I enjoyed it as much as my final score would indicate, but the high quality of this one is quickly and lastingly apparent. Overall, very good.

A- Pours a dark brown/amber hue that is surprisingly clear with a small, creamy off-white head that is mostly diminishing, minimal lacing
S- Nose is of dark fruit (plum, raisins), caramel malts, and sugary sweetness, soft alcohol tones and slight tones of toast/bread
T- Initial taste is of complex, malty caramel sweetness, some bitterness in the middle that quickly dissipates, finish is dry with Belgian sugar throughout
